title.narrative: Pulses, People, Planet & Profit - ICCO Lead partner

description.narrative: Pulses, People, Planet and Profit - own implementation

The Pulses, People, Planet and Profit (P4) project will work with smallholder farmers and labourers in four townships in Yangon and Magway Regions (Thongwa, Kayan, Magway and Min Bu).
The project, started in September 2017, will increase the incomes of 10,000 smallholder mungbean farmers, 20% of whom are landless female farm labourers. Pulses value chains, specifically for mungbeans, offer great potential to lift many Myanmar farmers and labourers out of poverty.
The key objectives of the P4 project are to improve the enabling environment for the mungbean value chain in Myanmar by proposing policy and regulatory reforms; to increase the volume of mungbeans purchased by premium market buyers from farmers groups by enhancing access to support services on Good Agricultural Practices, Climate Smart Agriculture and collective marketing; and to increase the mungbean farmers productivity and quality of produce by enhancing access to support services and good quality mungbean seeds.
ICCO Cooperation and the DaNa Facility, in collaboration with East West Seed (EWS) and Network Activities Group (NAG), have launched a 30-month UK Department for International Development (DFID)-funded project.

This project will increase the incomes of 10,000 smallholder mungbean farmers, 20% of whom are landless female farm labourers. Pulses value chains, specifically for mungbeans, offer great potential to lift many Myanmar farmers and labourers out of poverty.

title.narrative: Project image
Economic Empowerment - output
Number of people with an increase in income

comment.narrative: By 10 September 2019, P4 project tracked 7,781 unique households that have benefitted from the growth of the mungbean value chain. These households have benefitted from P4’s activities (not only training) based on key aspects demonstrating productivity (GAP applied farmers), quality (quality seed use) and marketing (collective buying and selling) approaches, and access to financial services (such as loans received from A-Bank).

this is the number of households engaging in collective selling and buying, but there may be more added after survey since labourers, women groups and other farmers trained by P4 are not yet included here)

title.narrative: Economic Empowerment - other
% increase in income of targeted landless female farm labourers

comment.narrative: In the reporting to DaNa Facility we will differentiate results (in USD) per township because of variety in local situation per township.
For 2,000 labourers
(see notes in logframe)
For 2,000 labourers

Seasonal labourers earned more compared to 2017 and 2018. Depending on variations between regions, harvesting times and volume of harvest, wages and number of days worked on mungbeans differed. Median increase compared to 2018: 32%
For 2,000 labourers

title.narrative: % increase in income of targeted poor smallholder farmers

comment.narrative: In the reporting to DaNa Facility we will differentiate results (in USD) per township because of variety in local situation per township.
For 8,000 male and female farmers
(see notes in logframe)
For 8,000 male and female farmers
Income per acre increased with 5% compared to 2018. Income per acre increased with 28% compared to baseline in 2017.
For 8,000 male and female farmers

title.narrative: Number of farmers (disaggregated by sex) who received support services from mungbean buyers and input suppliers during project period

comment.narrative: (% women yet unclear)

4182 individuals (3,012 male, 1,170 female).
In this past 6-month period: 3391 individuals (1055 women from female headed households) received loans from A-Bank, improving their access to finance.
Additionally, SMM provided training to 38 farmers (male 26, female 12) on seed treatment
Previous periods: 753 (Male 650, Female 103) received support and training from other companies.

title.narrative: Number of farmers and labourers engaged in collective marketing

comment.narrative: (18,8% women)
1427 farming households (143 are female headed households = 10%) were engaged in collective marketing.

title.narrative: % increase in volume of good quality mungbeans produced by targeted farmers

comment.narrative: (see notes in logframe)
17,8% (Thongwa)

Median across all regions: -4. Main cause: bad quality harvest in Minbuu. Other areas show good data.
Kayan: 0,66 MT/acre for grade A-A (GAP A)= 20% increase to 2018, 20% increase to baseline median. Magway: 0,15 MT/acre grade A-A (GAP A)= 5% increase to 2018, 5% decrease to baseline median. Minbuu: 0,36 MT/acre grade A-A (GAP A)= 33% decrease to 2018, 27% decrease to baseline median. Thongwa: 0,75 MT/acre grade A-A (GAP A)= 7% increase to 2018, 7% increase to baseline median.

title.narrative: % of targeted poor smallholder mungbean farmers and landless female farm labourers who perceive themselves empowered by beneftting from the growth and development of the mungbean value chain

comment.narrative: 70% of 10,000 farmers (of which 10% women farmers, and 20% female farm labourers)
(see notes in logframe)
70% of 10,000 farmers (of which 10% women farmers, and 20% female farm labourers)

In 2019, 51% of 417 survey respondents from P4 target group scored a positive average (note: medium to largely influencing their personal situation) on 5 empowerment questions. 44% of these are women. 42% of these respondents are from Yangon Region, the other 58% from Magway.
70% of 10,000 farmers (of which 10% women farmers, and 20% female farm labourers)

title.narrative: % increase in share of mungbeans bought by buyers from farmers groups and other mungbean suppliers

comment.narrative: (waiting for response from buyers) (indicator wording needs to be changed into '% share of mungbeans bought...')

This figure covers Yangon Region. MMTW company together with the Regional Farmer Development Association sold more than 1600 metric tonne of mungbeans collectively. Based on the 2019 seasonal assessment, 29% of baskets produced by respondents were sold to MMTW.
In Magway Region, the collective marketing of the Magway Regional Farmer Association for mungbean is still low, about 5%.

title.narrative: % increase in mungbean yield (metric tons per acre) by targeted farmers by applying GAP and CSA

comment.narrative: (see notes in logframe)

Overall, the median mungbean yield in metric tonne per acre increased with 16%. Note: there are substantial differences in productivity per acre between Yangon and Magway.
Compared to 2017 baseline: In Kayan: 32% increase In Thonegway: 7% increase In Magway: 50% increase In Minbu: no change

title.narrative: Number of input retail enterprises for mungbean inputs developed during project period

comment.narrative: 56 retail groups (women-led groups as well as retail groups linked to FDAs). The project provided funds for small scale business based on their business plan to 25 Women Groups (WGs) in Magway Region. In Yangon, 31 Women Groups (WGs) have already submitted their business plan and proposals to the project. Therefore, RFDA and responsible persons of project will review on their business plan based on check list and score card.

title.narrative: Number of buyers and input suppliers who provided support services to mungbean farmers during project period

comment.narrative: In total: 8 companies. Through the project, Armo Co Ltd., Green Farm Development Co Ltd., Taw Win Aung Co Ltd., Yara Mila Co Ltd. sold Agri-inputs to the farmers through collective purchasing by credit system with the lower interest rate. Myit Myat Taw Win Co Ltd. committed to support GAP sesame and mung bean farmers for collective selling, and labor management. Taung Paw Yi Shin farm machinery rental company could be linked to Yangon farmers for their rice.

title.narrative: Political space - other
Number of NGOs, CSOs and CBOs trained on lobby & advocacy

comment.narrative: (20% trained women)

title.narrative: Number of lobby & advocacy activities conducted by trained NGOs, CSOs and CBOs
Number of policy recommendations submitted by trained NGOs, CSOs and CBOs that are included by government in their agricultural reform agenda

comment.narrative: At the recent visit to the Myanmar parliament, P4 team was able to reiterate and bring input from farmer leaders to the parliamentarians. Core messages to the Amyothar Hluttaw committee related to the need to pay more attention to the pulses sector, to enforce and raise the penalties of illegal sale and misuse of pesticides, to further invest in quality by improving seed access, food safety testing laboratories, and restructuring of the Department of Agriculture to meet farmer demands.

In total 3 recommendations were provided: - Recommendations from P4 team provided to two Parliamentary Inquiry Committees and Union Level Department of Agriculture. We recommended key adaptation points and increased enforcement of the Pesticides Law. Also, need to put in place food testing laboratories, increased collaboration between private sector and CSOs. - GAP group certificates granted - The DoA stated a commitment to increasing number of staff assigned to mungbean crops

title.narrative: Number of farmers trained

comment.narrative: In total: 11,604 Households (without overlap) 1. Under output 1 L&A: 735 HHs 2. Under output 2 Marketing: 5270 HHs 3. Under output 3 GAP: 7292 HHs 4. Under output 4 Seed in Magway and Yangon: 1119 HHs 5. Under output 5: Demo plot 87 HHs
